text: Number 385, State of California, Petitioner, versus Harry Taylor et al.
May it please the Court.
May it please the Court.
May I -- may I ask you?
California --
Under the Federal Employers' Liability Act.
California, sir, has a -- an Act which permits suits against the State to a limited extent.
But it could be reviewed as wrong.
There's no doubt of it, sir.
That has been held to cover --
That has been held to cover the operation of this very railroad.
I understand that it covers suits under the F -- F.E.L.A.
Under -- under the F.E.L.A.
State court?
The state court.
I won't trouble you with it.
Counsel has described this railroad as a switching railroad.

Well, does that mean this, Mr. Williamson, that the employees in respect of higher tenure of employment, wages, seniority will be -- will no longer be embraced by any California statutes, civil service statutes that deal with those subjects?
Sir, I think the answer is that so far as the collective-bargaining agreement covers the particular points that is supreme.
Well --
-- that California law would still be there.
Let's take a -- let's take the matter of wages.
Yes, sir.
Well, perhaps if there is a question because I don't know the fact.
Yes, sir.
Are the wages prescribed by some state legislation which affixes ranges, for example, salary rates by ranges?
That -- that is correct, sir.
And are they on a salary basis by which I mean an annual basis, rather than weekly or monthly and so forth?
It -- it is by the hour in majority of instances, I believe.
Under the statute?
Under the -- I beg your pardon, under the collective-bargaining agreement --
No.
-- under California Act.
Yes.
As Mr. -- that's correct, sir.
Prevailing?
-- yes, in private employment.
But I take it in this instance if your position is correct.
That -- that is correct, sir.
And similarly, I suppose as to other --
In any place where there might be conflict.
Well, getting back to wages for a moment though.
I think that is correct, sometime by administrative -- some regulations.
Sometime?
I think, sometimes the legislation permits administrative regulation of wages.
Well now, if your position is correct, now would there be required either legislative or administrative action to confirm any collective-bargaining agreement provision which fixed wages?
I believe not, sir.
Now, how do you --
I believe it's very simple in fact.
How do you meet Mr. Wineg's point that there are other employees in related activities that is related to the railroad activity, well of course, would not be covered by -- if you prevail?
Well, I think there would be no trouble because the other employees would not be in the railroad labor world.
Well, I gather --
And the other employees, I believe, sir, are -- are not in that class or craft.

Well, I have the impressions from this argument, I may be wrong about it, but there was a direct relation between the compensation paid to the railroad employees and these other employees in activities somehow related to the railroad work.
Well, how closely related they are.
